a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Indeed, when God-consciousness [taqwa] endures and conviction [tasdiq] in the ultimate good [al-husna] in the Hereafter strengthens, patience [sabr] is made easy. And for this reason, the Most High said: "As for he who gives and is God-conscious [ittaqa] and affirms the ultimate good [al-husna], We will ease his way to ease." And the example of this division is the wrestler's power over another. For the strong man is able to overpower the weak with the slightest charge and easiest exertion, such that he meets no fatigue [i'ya'] or weariness [lughub] in wrestling him, nor is his self [nafs] disturbed, nor is he bewildered, whereas he cannot overpower the strong except with toil, increased effort, and sweat upon the brow. Thus is the wrestling between the motivator of religion [din] and the motivator of base desire [hawa], for it is, in truth, a wrestling between the soldiers of the angels and the soldiers of the devils. Whenever the appetites [shahawat] submit and are subdued, and the motivator of religion [din] gains mastery and takes control, and patience [sabr] is made easy through constant perseverance, that bequeaths the station [maqam] of contentment [rida], as will come in the Book of Contentment. For contentment [rida] is higher than patience [sabr].

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And these fluctuations and wonders of the creation of God the Exalted in their fluctuation from where knowledge does not guide to it, none know them except the observers and those who watch over their states with God the Exalted. And the hearts in steadfastness upon the good and the evil and the hesitation between them are three: a heart that has been inhabited by piety (Taqwa) and purified by spiritual discipline (Riyada) and cleansed from the impurities of character traits (Akhlaq), sparks of good from the treasuries of the unseen (Ghayb) and the entrances of the dominion (Malakut) ignite in it, so the intellect (Aql) turns to reflecting upon what has occurred to it to know the subtleties of the good in it and to become aware of the secrets of its benefits, so its aspect is unveiled to it by the light of insight (Basira), so it judges that it must be done, so it urges it upon it and calls it to act by it. And the angel (Malak) looks at the heart and finds it good in its essence, pure by its piety (Taqwa), illuminated by the radiance of the intellect (Aql), inhabited by the lights of knowledge (Ma'rifa), so he sees it suitable to be for him a dwelling and a descent, so at that time he supplies it with unseen troops and guides it to other goodnesses until good leads to good, and likewise perpetually, and his supply with encouragement to good and facilitation of the matter for it does not cease. And to it is the allusion by His saying the Exalted: 'So as for he who gave and was pious (Taqwa) and believed in the best, We will ease him to the ease.' And in such a heart shines the light of the lamp from the niche of lordship (Rububiyya) until the hidden polytheism (Shirk) which is more hidden than the crawling of the black ant on a dark night is not concealed in it, so nothing hidden is concealed from this light, and nothing from the tricks of Satan (Shaytan) deceives it, rather Satan stands and inspires adorned speech as delusion, so it does not pay attention to it. And this heart after its purification from the destructive things becomes, in proximity, inhabited by the saving things which we will mention: gratitude (Shukr), patience (Sabr), fear (Khawf), hope (Raja'), poverty (Faqr), asceticism (Zuhd), love (Mahabbah), contentment (Rida'), longing (Shawq), reliance (Tawakkul), reflection (Tafakkur), self-accounting (Muhasabah), and others. And it is the heart upon which God the Mighty and Majestic has turned His face, and it is the contented heart intended by His saying the Exalted: 'Unquestionably, by the remembrance (Dhikr) of God hearts are contented,' and by His saying the Mighty and Majestic: 'O contented soul (Nafs).'

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
Rather His statement, the Exalted: 'And there is not one of you except that he will enter it' is like the explicit in that this is inevitable for all since no believer is free from a sin he commits. And His statement, the Exalted: 'None will burn in it except the most wretched, who denied and turned away' intended by it from a specific group or intended by 'the most wretched' a specific person also. If you say: What is the doubt of the Mu'tazila and Murji'a and what is the proof of the invalidity of their statement? I say: Their doubt is the generalities of the Quran. As for the Murji'a, they said: The believer does not enter the Fire even if he commits all sins, due to His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: 'So whoever believes in his Lord, he fears no loss nor any injustice' and due to His saying, the Blessed and Exalted: 'And those who believe in Allah and His messengers - those are the truthful ones' the verse, and due to His saying: 'Whenever a group is thrown into it, its keepers will ask them' until His saying: 'So we denied and said: Allah has not sent down anything' so His saying 'Whenever a group is thrown into it' is general, so it should be that whoever is thrown into the Fire is a denier, and due to His saying: 'None will burn in it except the most wretched, who denied and turned away' and this is restriction, affirmation, and negation, and due to His saying: 'Whoever comes with a good deed will have better than it, and they will be safe from terror that Day' so Faith (Iman) is the head of good deeds, and due to His saying: 'And Allah loves the doers of good' and He said: 'Indeed, We do not allow to be lost the reward of any who does good deeds' and they have no proof in that, for wherever Faith (Iman) is mentioned in these verses, it is intended as Faith (Iman) with action, since we have clarified that Faith (Iman) may be used and intended as Islam, which is agreement with the Heart (Qalb), speech, and action. The evidence for this interpretation is many reports about punishing the disobedient and the measures of punishment, and his saying: 'He will be brought out of the Fire whoever had in his heart an atom's weight of faith (Iman)' so how can he be brought out if he did not enter?
